description: From Middle English bolle (“pod; shell”) and Middle Dutch bolle (“round object”); both ultimately from Proto-Germanic *bullô (“round object; bowl”). More at bowl.

entries.meaning: The rounded seed-bearing capsule of a cotton or flax plant.
examples: The champion picker of the day before was the hero of the dawn. If he prophesied that the cotton in today’s field was going to be sparse and stick to the bolls like glue, every listener would grunt a hearty agreement.

entries.meaning: A protuberance or excrescence growing on the trunks of some trees, a burl.
(Scotland) An old dry measure equal to six bushels.

verbs.description: boll (third-person singular simple present bolls, present participle bolling, simple past and past participle bolled)

entries.meaning: To form a boll or seed vessel; to go to seed.
